title: Water Use
description: Comprehensive water use requirements including water source assessment, risk assessment, water reuse protocols, antimicrobial treatment monitoring, microbiological testing, sampling procedures, corrective actions, source inspections, backflow prevention, and water storage

requirements.text: What source(s) of water is used in the operation? Information gathering question
mandatoryStatements: This is an information gathering question
Response identifies all water sources used in operation
Examples: municipal, well, surface water, recycled/reclaimed, rainwater
Information used to determine applicable water quality requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Documentation of all water sources used in operation
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Update information when water sources change

requirements.text: What is this water source used for (e.g., irrigation, crop protection, fertigation, etc.)? Information gathering question
mandatoryStatements: This is an information gathering question
Response identifies how water sources are used
Examples: irrigation, crop protection, fertigation, cleaning, cooling
Information used to determine risk level and testing requirements
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Update information when water uses change

requirements.text: What types of irrigation methods are used (e.g., micro-irrigation, overhead, drip, flood, hydroponic (specify type))? Information gathering question
mandatoryStatements: This is an information gathering question
Response identifies irrigation methods used
Examples: micro-irrigation, overhead, drip, flood, hydroponic systems
For hydroponics, specific type should be identified
Information used to assess water contact and contamination risks
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Update information when irrigation methods change

requirements.text: Does the water come in contact with the edible portion of the crop? Information gathering question
mandatoryStatements: This is an information gathering question
Response indicates if water directly contacts edible portions
Direct contact increases food safety risk
Information determines appropriate water quality standards
requirements.verificationExpectations: Documentation of water contact with edible portions
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Reassess when irrigation methods or crops change

requirements.text: Is water captured and re-used? Information gathering question
mandatoryStatements: This is an information gathering question
Response indicates if water is captured and reused
Water reuse requires specific monitoring and treatment controls
Information determines need for reuse procedures (question 3.11.03)
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Update information when water management practices change

requirements.text: Is there a documented risk assessment in place for all water used in the operation?
mandatoryStatements: Risk assessment is documented for all water sources and uses
Assessment evaluates microbiological hazards
Assessment evaluates chemical hazards (heavy metals, nitrates, etc.)
Assessment considers water source characteristics and vulnerabilities
Assessment evaluates water application methods and contact with edible portions
Assessment identifies appropriate water quality standards
Risk assessment is reviewed and updated at least annually
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of water risk assessment, update when sources or uses change
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Quarterly verification that water controls align with risk assessment

requirements.text: Where the risk assessment identifies the need for control of any hazards, are these controls indicated in the assessment and implemented?
mandatoryStatements: Water risk assessment identifies specific controls for each hazard
Controls are clearly documented in the assessment
All identified controls are implemented in operations
Controls may include treatment, testing, monitoring, or application method changes
Controls are appropriate for the identified risks
Implementation of controls is verified through monitoring and testing
Records demonstrate ongoing implementation of water controls
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly verification that all water controls are implemented and effective
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily or continuous monitoring of critical water controls

requirements.text: Where water is re-used, are there specific Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the monitoring of anti-microbial parameters and changing of re-used water systems?
mandatoryStatements: If water is reused, SOPs are documented for water system management
SOPs specify antimicrobial parameters to monitor (chlorine, pH, etc.)
SOPs define monitoring frequency for reused water
SOPs specify when water must be changed or replaced
SOPs address water treatment requirements for reuse
SOPs define acceptance criteria for reused water quality
Personnel are trained on water reuse procedures
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of water reuse SOP compliance and effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily or per-shift monitoring of reused water parameters per SOP

requirements.text: Where anti-microbial water treatments (e.g., chlorination, PAA, U.V., ozone, etc.) are required, are there records of the monitoring frequencies, results and where necessary the corrective actions?
mandatoryStatements: If antimicrobial water treatment is used, monitoring records are maintained
Records document monitoring frequency (continuous, hourly, daily as appropriate)
Records show treatment parameter results (chlorine level, UV intensity, etc.)
Monitoring frequency is appropriate for risk and treatment type
Records document corrective actions when parameters are out of specification
Treatment equipment maintenance is documented
Records demonstrate consistent effective treatment
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly review of water treatment monitoring records and corrective actions
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous or frequent monitoring of water treatment parameters, immediate corrective action if out of specification

requirements.text: Are there results for microbiological tests conducted on the water (taken from the closest practical point of use) at the required and/or expected frequency? A ZERO POINT (NON-CONFORMANCE) DOWN SCORE IN THIS QUESTION RESULTS IN AUTOMATIC FAILURE OF THIS AUDIT.
mandatoryStatements: Microbiological testing of water is conducted at required frequency
Samples are taken from closest practical point of use
Testing frequency is appropriate for water source, use, and risk
Testing includes appropriate indicators (generic E. coli, coliforms, etc.)
Test results are documented and retained
Testing is performed by qualified laboratory
Testing frequency meets regulatory and best practice requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of water testing records for frequency and compliance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Testing performed on schedule, immediate review of results when received

requirements.text: Do written procedures (SOPs) exist covering proper sampling protocols which include where samples should be taken and how samples should be identified?
mandatoryStatements: Written water sampling procedures (SOPs) are documented
SOPs specify sampling locations (point of use, source, etc.)
SOPs describe proper sampling technique to prevent contamination
SOPs specify sample identification and labeling requirements
SOPs address sample handling and transportation
SOPs identify who is qualified to collect samples
Personnel are trained on sampling procedures
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of water sampling SOPs, verification that procedures are followed
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Verification of proper sampling technique during sample collection events

requirements.text: Do written procedures (SOPs) exist covering corrective action measures for unsuitable or abnormal water testing results?
mandatoryStatements: Written corrective action procedures exist for unsuitable water test results
SOPs define what constitutes unsuitable or abnormal results
SOPs specify immediate response actions (cease use, switch source, etc.)
SOPs define investigation and root cause analysis requirements
SOPs address resampling and retesting protocols
SOPs identify who has authority to make decisions on water suitability
SOPs define when operations can resume after unsuitable results
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of water corrective action SOPs, verification of implementation when unsuitable results occur
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate implementation of corrective action procedures when unsuitable results received

requirements.text: If unsuitable or abnormal results have been detected, have documented corrective measures been performed?
mandatoryStatements: If unsuitable water results occurred, corrective measures are documented
Documentation shows immediate actions taken to protect product
Documentation shows investigation of root cause
Documentation shows corrective actions implemented
Documentation shows verification that corrective actions were effective
Product disposition is documented if water contact occurred
Corrective actions follow established SOPs
requirements.verificationExpectations: Review of corrective action documentation for completeness and effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate documentation of all corrective actions when unsuitable results occur

requirements.text: Are there records (with corrective actions) of periodic visual inspection of the condition of water source(s)?
mandatoryStatements: Periodic visual inspections of water sources are conducted
Inspection records document condition of water sources
Inspections look for contamination risks, turbidity, debris, etc.
Inspection frequency is appropriate for source type and risk
Corrective actions are documented when issues identified
Inspections verify source protection measures are effective
Records link inspection findings to any necessary follow-up actions
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of water source inspection records
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly or monthly visual inspections of water sources depending on risk

requirements.text: Where applicable, are there backflow prevention devices on all main lines, including where chemical, fertilizer and pesticide applications are made?
mandatoryStatements: Backflow prevention devices are installed where required
Devices are on main water lines to prevent contamination
Devices are installed where chemicals are injected into water systems
Devices are installed where fertilizers are applied through water systems
Devices are installed where pesticides are applied through water systems
Backflow preventers are tested and maintained per regulations
Testing and maintenance records are maintained
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual testing and inspection of backflow prevention devices
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Annual backflow preventer testing by qualified personnel, immediate repair if failures detected

requirements.text: If the operation stores water (tank, cistern, container), are the storage containers well maintained?
mandatoryStatements: If water is stored, storage containers are well maintained
Containers are structurally sound without cracks or leaks
Containers are covered or enclosed to prevent contamination
Containers prevent pest and debris entry
Containers are cleaned and sanitized on regular schedule
Container materials are appropriate for potable water storage
Inspection and maintenance records for storage containers are maintained
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly inspection of water storage container condition and maintenance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly visual inspection of water storage containers, immediate repair of damage or contamination risks

capaInject: If water risk assessment not documented: develop assessment within 30 days, implement interim controls immediately
If water controls not implemented: immediate implementation of critical controls, complete all controls within 14 days
If water reuse SOPs not documented: document procedures within 14 days, enhance monitoring until SOPs complete
If antimicrobial treatment monitoring inadequate: immediate enhancement of monitoring, equipment check within 24 hours
If water testing not performed at required frequency: immediate testing, establish testing schedule, make up missed tests within 7 days
If unsuitable water test results: immediate cessation of water use, switch to alternative source, investigation within 24 hours, corrective actions before resuming use
If backflow prevention not adequate: immediate installation of temporary measures, permanent backflow preventers within 30 days
If water storage containers poorly maintained: immediate cleaning and repair, enhanced inspection until permanently corrected
traceabilityInject: Water sources must be traceable to specific uses and growing areas
Water treatment monitoring records must be traceable to specific water systems and dates
Water testing results must be traceable to specific sources, sampling locations, and dates
Corrective actions for water issues must be traceable to specific test results and affected areas/products
Backflow preventer testing must be traceable to specific devices and test dates
